snippet.title: Seven Network poised to capitalise on Ninja Warrior success
snippet.content:
The Seven Network is searching for ways to capitalise on the success of Australian Ninja Warrior with meetings being held to secure a similar format. Nine Network's Australian Ninja Warrior has been the most successful television format of the year to date, smashing its primetime rivals Yummy Mummies and MasterChef. Despite its short season, the show's grand finale became the most watched non-sport program of 2017.
Up Next
Rachel Griffiths speaks against orphanage tourism

Entertainment news highlights
Bitchiness on The Bachelor, Dr G Yunupingu's marvelous career, talk shows take on Trump's transgender ban, fans' anger at Australian Ninja Warrior and Ringo and Paul back together again.
Now creators of similar shows are circling the Seven Network to help them cash in on the current wave of interest in fitness-themed reality programs. Industry sources said Seven is considering airing an Australian version of Spartan: Ultimate Team Challenge.Photo: Nine Network But it is understood the licensee of that format has approached Seven but a deal has not yet been reached between the two. Sources within Seven confirmed the network is interested in securing a sports entertainment show.
Spartan: Ultimate Team Challenge originated in the United States and sees teams of five tackle a one-mile obstacle course in a bid to win a $US250,000 prize.
You will now receive updates from

The teams are comprised of two men and two women who are matched with an "elite Spartan athlete" who is picked by the show and is the team captain. The first season premiere was watched by 4.8 million people in America, with the final episode, the Season One Championship watched by 3.23 million people. The second season didn't fare as well with just 2.19 million tuning in for the finale. The show is broadcast on NBC in the US and on Foxtel in Australia.
